Award.AwardTitle: Social Indicators for Rural Alaska Communities (SIRAC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project aims to determine how social conditions for Alaska Natives living in small arctic communities have changed since 2000, and differ among communities and small regions. The Census Long Form Survey historically provided much of the data for measuring social and economic conditions in the U.S. Its replacement with the American Community Survey (ACS) after the 2000 Census has raised serious concerns about whether Census data continue to provide accurate measures of well-being in rural Alaska communities, at a time when the region faces unprecedented environmental and socio-economic change. The project addresses the uncertainty with ACS data by developing a new set of social, economic, and cultural indicators with increased capability to detect differences at local scales.

Specific objectives include: (1) systematically examine the reliability of ACS data for rural Alaska by disaggregating published margins of error into components expressing dispersion across communities, years, and individuals; (2) construct socio-economic indicators for rural Alaska communities and regions with substantially smaller margins of error than published results; (3) estimate key indicators for communities where observations are sparse or missing entirely; and (4) test whether communities and regions have changed or differ significantly with respect to one or more indicators. The project pursues these objectives through modeling and statistical analyses of multiple primary data sources, including individual interview data from the ACS and the previous censuses in cooperation with the U.S. Census Bureau. Project outputs include a set of socio-economic indicators with improved reliability over published ACS figures that can help state and local governments and non-governmental organizations allocate funds, plan, and evaluate social service and economic development programs. A pioneering application of data assimilation with a social system model aids arctic social observing system design by revealing highest priority targets for new data collection for observing and understanding social change in arctic communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Community Survey (ACS) replaced the Census Long Form after 2000 as the main source of source of information on social and economic conditions nationwide and the only systematic source for Alaska Native people living in rural communities. Although the questions remained largely the same, the Census Bureau made several changes in methods and reporting, and data users -- researchers, public officials, other stakeholders -- have expressed concerns about the integrity of the data. The SIRAC project investigated these concerns as it used ACS data to determine how social and economic conditions for rural Alaska Native communities have changed since 2000.

Specific project objectives included:

  1. Understanding sources of the high published margins of error in ACS estimates for key indicators for rural Alaska communities;

  2. Constructing experimental new estimates of the census socioeconomic indicators for rural Alaska communities with substantially smaller margins of error than published results;

  3. Providing new community-level estimates of key indicators where observations in the ACS are sparse or missing entirely;

  4. Testing hypotheses about social and economic conditions in rural Alaska communities since 2000.

To achieve these objectives, project researchers worked with the Census Bureau?s Center for Economic Studies to access individual ACS and Census records at the University of Southern California Census Research Data Center. Project outcomes as they related to each objective were as follows:

 

Objective 1. Analysis of sources of error in estimates of income and earnings -- two indicators that are likely to change from year to year -- indicated that up to 15 percent of the margin of error comes from systematic year-to-year differences common to all rural Alaska communities, such as from fluctuations in the national and state economies and Permanent Fund Dividend (PFD) payments. Investigation of the data also uncovered two significant sources of error not included in published error margins, which just address error due to sampling. The most significant deficiency arises from the Census Bureau decision to not request or record information in the survey on income of children under age 15. This policy may have minimal consequences in most states, but it has caused substantial underreporting of income in Alaska, where nearly all children receive PFDs, and thousands of Alaska Native children also receive dividends from several Alaska Native Regional Corporations that enrolled descendants of original beneficiaries. Project research determined that underreporting of PFD income in the ACS results in underreporting of the number of Alaskans with incomes below the federal poverty threshold by 10-15 percent. Another source of non-sampling error derives from miscoding previous state of residence for interstate migrants. Project research determined that the coding error led to over-estimation of out-migration from Alaska by about 40,000 people annually for many years. Researchers shared these findings on both these issues with Census Bureau officials. The Census Bureau identified the source of the coding error and fixed it, but has taken no action on income of children.

 

Objectives 2 and 3. Project researchers used statistical analysis of data from the 2000 Census Longform, ACS, and the Alaska Department of Labor to construct experimental estimates of 8 social and economic indicators for all rural Alaska communities on income, earnings, poverty, educational attainment and language retention. Unlike published data, which are 5-year moving averages, and lack estimates for years between 2000 and 2005, the synthetic data include annual estimates for all years between 2000 and 2016. Margins of error for the constructed estimates are comparable or smaller than those of published results, and adjust for the two sources of non-sampling error addressed above. These estimates will be publicly released as son as the Census Bureau completes its review to insure that the estimates do not compromise privacy of the source data.

 

Objective 4. Researchers used ACS data to test a number of hypotheses about effects of social innovations unique to Alaska on well-being, and effects on mobility in rural Alaska Native communities. Well-being hypotheses included the effects of the Permanent Fund Dividend on poverty, benefits of ANCSA individual beneficiaries after 40 years, effects of the Western Alaska Community Development Quota (CDQ), and long term effects for local residents of hired to work at the Red Dog mine on earnings and mobility. Mobility hypotheses included quality of local public services on intercommunity migration, and the stepping stones hypothesis on patterns of urban-rural migration. Few of these findings have been published to date; they remain under disclosure review by the Census Bureau and in peer review, and will be disseminated to researchers and stakeholders as soon as they are available.

 

In addition to sharing findings about the quality of ACS data with state, federal, and local stakeholders, the project provided financial support and opportunities for research training for three students, including two Alaska Native individuals.
